EXPERIMENT NO-1  
 
A. Review of MATLAB commands 
Lab Task-1: Learn the use of common MATLAB Library /graphic functions  
Revise   the   basic   commands,   concepts   of   array   indexing,   script   files,   functions,   and 
vectorization.  Use  help  command  and  make  sure  you  know  how  to  use  plot,  subplot,  title, 
xlabel, ylabel, stem, grid, and axis. Check the use of scatter function also. Learn how to use 
legend, dotted-dashed lines with circles, squares and / or different colours.  
 
Lab Task-2 : Generation and display of discrete-time sequences in MATLAB 
We need several elementary sequences in digital signal processing for analysis purposes:  
unit impulse sequence, unit step sequence, exponential sequence (both real and complex-
valued), sinusoidal sequence and random sequences. Write general MATLAB functions for 
these  and  use  them  to  solve  the  following  type  of  exercises.  Check  the  use  of  xtilde  to 
generate periodic sequences.

B. Convolution and Impulse response 
Objectives:  
1 Implementation of linear and circular convolution on sequences 
2.  Design an N-point moving average filter (FIR filter) 
Notes:  
1. Revise  the  important  relation  between  convolution  and  impulse  response  studied  in 
your  Signals  and  Networks  course.    We  extend  the  same  to  Discrete-time  systems. 
MATLAB  provides  a  built-in  function  called  conv  that  computes  the  convolution 
between two finite-duration sequences.  Be careful that the conv function assumes that 
the two sequences begin at n = 0, while Matlab arrays start indexing from n= 1. This 
experiment will build the important concept that multiplication in the frequency domain 
for  discrete signals  is  equivalent  to  a  different  type  of  convolution,  called  Circular

experiment will build the important concept that multiplication in the frequency domain 
for  discrete signals  is  equivalent  to  a  different  type  of  convolution,  called  Circular 
Convolution and you need to understand the theory of what is the difference in the two. 
Take  arbitrary  sequences,  do  hand-calculations  of  convolution  and  verify  using  the 
corresponding built-in MATLAB convolution functions. Check Theory Notes supplied.

Lab  task  3 : Execute  the  following codes  for  Circular  convolution  of  two  arbitrary 
sequences using the commands below. You can verify your result using the  “cconv” 
command.

2. The design of digital filters through the MATLAB function filter to compute averages 
along a vector of data. The Moving Average filter is widely used in DSP for smoothing 
noisy data and is one of the easiest of all digital filters to understand. It is particularly 
effective at removing high-frequency random noise from a signal. The moving average 
filter operates by taking the arithmetic mean, or average value, of a number of past input 
samples,  in  order  to  form  each  output  sample.    It  slides  a  window  of the  appropriate 
length, say N.  This may be represented by the following 
  
The corresponding difference equation will be  
Y[n] = 1/N { x[n]+x[n-1]+....+x[n-(N-1)]} 
Can you write the impulse response and frequency response of the MA filter? Can you justify 
that  it  is  a  LPF?  The  moving  average  actually  performs  a convolution of  the  input 
sequence x[n] with a rectangular pulse of length N and height 1/N (to make the area of the

that  it  is  a  LPF?  The  moving  average  actually  performs  a convolution of  the  input 
sequence x[n] with a rectangular pulse of length N and height 1/N (to make the area of the 
pulse, and, hence, the gain of the filter, one). What will be the “dual” of this filter?  Discuss.  
 
Lab Task-4 : implement a N-point MA filter as a function and analyse effect of changing N  
a. First  learn  how  the  “filter”  command  works,  and  compute  the  numerator  and 
denominator for the filter transfer function.  
b. Create a row vector of   the given data, corrupt it with random noise or add a higher
